citeinfo.title: U.S. Gulf of Mexico coast (TX, MS, AL, and FL) Macroclimate Vegetation Data Section 1 (2013-2014)

descript.abstract: The northern Gulf of Mexico coast spans two major climate gradients and represents an excellent natural laboratory for developing climate-influenced ecological models. In this project, we used these zones of remarkable transition to develop macroclimate-based models for quantifying the regional responses of coastal wetland ecosystems to climate variation. In addition to providing important fish and wildlife habitat and supporting coastal food webs, these coastal wetlands provide many ecosystem goods and services including clean water, stable coastlines, food, recreational opportunities, and stored carbon. Our objective was to examine and forecast the effects of macroclimatic drivers on wetland ecosystem structure and function in the northern Gulf of Mexico.
descript.purpose: The northern Gulf of Mexico coast spans two major climate gradients and represents an excellent natural laboratory for developing climate-influenced ecological models. In this project, we used these zones of remarkable transition to develop macroclimate-based models for quantifying the regional responses of coastal wetland ecosystems to climate variation. In addition to providing important fish and wildlife habitat and supporting coastal food webs, these coastal wetlands provide many ecosystem goods and services including clean water, stable coastlines, food, recreational opportunities, and stored carbon. Our objective was to examine and forecast the effects of macroclimatic drivers on wetland ecosystem structure and function in the northern Gulf of Mexico.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Geological Survey, Wetland and Aquatic Research Center

idinfo.native: Environment as of Metadata Creation: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.3.1 (Build 4959) Service Pack N/A (Build N/A)

attracc.attraccr: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted
dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

horizpa.horizpar: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

vertacc.vertaccr: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

procstep.procdesc: In each 1 m^2 plot, we estimated percent cover for all plant species below 1.4 m, percent cover for all species above 1.4 m, and measured mean canopy and maximum vegetation heights. If any plant within a visualized 100 m^2 plot (5 x 20 m; long edge parallel to the shoreline) centered on the 1 m^2 plot was > 1.4 m tall, we also estimated percent cover for all plant species and maximum plant height within that 100 m^2 plot. We quantified light interception in each 1 m^2 plot as a proxy for standing plant biomass by measuring light intensity at various heights using a linear ceptometer (sensu Whitbeck and Grace 2006). For short-statured plots, we measured light intensity at ground level and above the vegetation canopy. For tall-statured plots (e.g., in woodlands), we measured light at ground level, at 1.4 m outside the canopy (in direct sunlight), and, if there was a low-statured understory, at 1.4 m within the plot under the canopy.

spdoinfo.indspref: GNIS placenames: Corpus Christi, Texas, Port Aransas, Texas, San Antonio, Texas, Galveston, Texas, Slidell, Louisiana, Grand Bay, Mississippi, Weeks Bay, Alabama, Tampa Bay, Florida, and Ten Thousand Islands, Florida.

enttyp.enttypd: A spreadsheet containing each plot's vegetation and light coverage

attrdomv.udom: (1) a visible change in plant species dominance (i.e., a zone transition or ecotone), (2) a 15 cm change in elevation from the previous plot, or (3) horizontal movement of 20 m from the previous plot within the same vegetation zone.

distinfo.distliab: Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from the U.S. Geological Survey server, and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata associated with this data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.
